recent_posts.title: BIP for Serverless Payjoin (AdamISZ)
recent_posts.summary:
- The email addresses the need for standardizing a protocol.
- The concern highlighted is the use of base64 encoding for the psk in the URI.
- The suggestion is to use base64url instead, as it is more suitable for this purpose.

recent_posts.title: segwit naming ambiguity
recent_posts.summary:
- The email discusses if "is_segwit" matches all segwit versions, including "p2wsh" and "p2wpkh".
- The current term used to encompass "p2wsh or p2wpkh but not p2tr" is "segwit_v0".
- Andrew Poelstra, Director of Research at Blockstream, provides this information in the email.

recent_posts.title: BIP for Serverless Payjoin
recent_posts.summary:
- The timing correlation and metadata intersection in transactions raise concern.
- Multiple factors combined could cause issues, although timing correlation alone may not be significant.
- Random padding of Payjoin PSBT message size is suggested to address the issue.

recent_posts.title: Multipath Keysend
recent_posts.summary:
- The email suggests revisiting a post-PTLCs scenario for Pay to Lightning Channel.
- Classic keysend should be made MPP, as CLN and LDK already support this feature.
- Recipients have the option to claim less than the amount sent in lightning MPP payments.

recent_posts.title: Blinded Paths Doom Scenario
recent_posts.summary:
- Tony and Bastien discuss deanonymizing techniques on the Lightning Network, specifically how the recipient can be deanonymized but not the sender.
- They mention the scenario of a major Lightning Service Provider with direct routes to every node and unannounced channels, raising privacy concerns.
- Blinded paths are introduced as a potential solution to preserve sender privacy on mobile wallets.

recent_posts.title: Specification Meeting Transcripts
recent_posts.summary:
- The team has been recording and transcribing their bi-weekly specification meetings.
- The records are shared for others to access at https://btctranscripts.com/lightning-specification.
- Gurwinder from Chaincode manually checks the accuracy of the transcripts.

active_posts.title: Blinded 2-party Musig2
active_posts.summary:
- We are implementing a version of 2-of-2 Schnorr Musig2 for statechains.
- The server will be fully 'blinded' and not learn the aggregate public key or signature.
- Security relies on the statechain server reporting the number of partial signatures.

active_posts.title: Ark: An Alternative Privacy-preserving Second Layer Solution
active_posts.summary:
- Ark, a new second-layer protocol, provides an alternative approach to the Lightning network.
- Ark uses virtual UTXOs (vTXOs) to send and receive funds without liquidity constraints.
- Ark's anonymous, off-chain payments are enabled through an untrusted intermediary called the Ark Service Provider (ASP).

active_posts.title: BIP-352 Silent Payments addresses should have an expiration time
active_posts.summary:
- Wallets can be compromised or lost, leading to toxic addresses and lost funds.
- Silent Payments allow multiple payments to a single address without privacy concerns.
- Adding an expiration date to Silent Payment addresses prevents harm, with ample time for expiration.

active_posts.title: Potential vulnerability in Lightning backends: BOLT-11 "payment hash" does not commit to payment!
active_posts.summary:
- LNbits team discovered and patched an exploit allowing attackers to create balances through invoices.
- Similar exploits in Lightning applications related to custodial wallets, payment processors, and account management software are possible.
- To mitigate the issue, backends should use unique "checking id's" or implement additional checks.

active_posts.title: Jamming Mitigation Dry Run
active_posts.summary:
- We are proceeding with the plan to validate local reputation algorithms using real-world data.
- The plan includes collecting forwarding data, propagating an experimental TLV, and implementing local reputation algorithms.
- We prioritize privacy, encourage node operators to participate, and provide more details in the email.
